snippet.title: From little things, big marketing ideas grow
snippet.content: WHAT a roller-coaster ride it has been. In the late 1980s, two Australian brothers (both food scientists) frustrated with the short life of culinary herbs developed the Eva Fresh technology which extended the natural shelf life of fresh herbs, without the need of heat treatment or acidification which can destroy delicate flavours. In the early 1990s, the Department of Primary Industries was working on a project to help Central Queensland cotton growers change their crops from cotton to herbs, as cotton is a high water-consumption plant with low yields and herbs are lower water-consumption and high yield. The farmers began trials of growing culinary herbs and in the late 1990s, Berri, which had purchased the Eva Fresh technology, and the Biloela farmers joined forces and the first seed (coriander) was planted on March 1, 1998. The Gourmet Garden brand was launched in late 1998 with a range of 10 stir-in herbs and spice pastes. It operated out of the Suncoast juice facility in Palmwoods. Suncoast Juice had been around since the 1970s and during the 1990s was a juice- processing facility for Berri Ltd. All the major supermarkets in Australia at the time sold Gourmet Garden. The Botanical Food Company saw the brand as a product range with global capability and appeal. The brand was quickly launched into the UK with a joint- venture partner in 2000, with New Zealand following in 2001. The biggest distribution opportunity was the North American market. The first potential customer we engaged with in the US thought we had rocks in our heads for coming up with the concept. We had a plan to launch in 1000 supermarkets through multiple retailers on the west coast of the US late in 2002. That way we could control our production capabilities. After we presented the Gourmet Garden concept to the first customer, he said he could put us in 1000 stores but we would have to stretch further than just the west coast. This distribution expansion continued to move east with Gourmet Garden's production capabilities building in Palmwoods. The expansion of the North American market continued, with distribution into Canada in 2003 and a legal entity was established in the US state of California in October 2007 with a small team of dedicated people. Distribution continued to build to the point where Gourmet Garden was being sold in more than 20,000 supermarkets across North America. The project to build a new facility started in early 2006 and was operational in October 2006. This new facility has enabled us to process enough product to expand into additional countries around the globe and continue to supply the ever-increasing demand in existing markets. Craig Smith is Gourmet Garden's Head of Sales in Asia.
